Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: BP 1 - Microwaveable Bioplastic Packaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase II SBIR research develops innovative nanotechnology to allow the use of bioplastics for food packaging. Polylactic acid (PLA) is an environmentally beneficial bioplastic made from renewable resources; however, the properties of PLA are limited. This makes it unsuited for use in microwaveable food packaging. In Phase I, university expertise resulting from earlier NSF funding was used to formulate a bioplastic with suitable properties, including cost. In Phase II, a viable manufacturing route towards food packing trays will be demonstrated at the pilot plant level working in close collaboration with a large industrial manufacturing partner.

The broader impacts of this Phase II SBIR research will be manifold. The new bioplastics are quantitatively more environmentally benign that petroplastics. Bioplastics are made form renewable resources and therefore simultaneously help decrease dependence on foreign oil while providing environmental benefits. Using a domestic biomass resource provides a competitive advantage against low labor cost manufacturers like China helping to stem job losses in the plastics industries. Presently, polystyrene is largely used for tray applications and foamed with 3-5 weight percent hydrocarbons. PLA can be foamed with carbon dioxide so the new technology has the additional benefit of displacing at least 1 million pounds per year of the pollutant volatile organic carbons (VOCs).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large quantities of petroleum are used to produce plastic, but oil supplies are finite and as world economies develop they will be increasingly expensive. Increasing costs of petro-plastics provides very lucrative opportunities for supplying alternative materials.  PolyNEW’s Phase II SBIR project sought to develop and rapidly commercialize next-generation bioplastics that are price-performance competitive with existing petroleum-based materials. The main barrier to using PLA bioplastic in hot food applications is that the PLA has a low heat distortion temperature (HDT), ie it does not hold its shape when heated. PolyNEW has been able to improve the heat resistance (HDT) and impact properties of the bioplastic using almost entirely renewable additives.  The intellectual merit of the project rests in innovative nanotechnology, based on renewable cellulosic nanowhiskers, to meet the performance goals for hot food packaging.  To date, all indications are that the materials have the needed physical properties for a wide variety of applications and that they can be produced economically.

 

The new bioplastics are quantitatively more environmentally benign than petroplastics. Bioplastics are made from renewable resources and therefore simultaneously help decrease dependence on foreign oil while providing environmental benefits. Using a domestic biomass resource provides a competitive advantage against low labor cost manufacturers like China helping to stem job losses in the plastics industries. New commercially competitive technology has been produced and will be transferred to a domestic manufacturer. Green job growth can be achieved not only in manufacturing but also in agriculture as new markets for bioproducts are developed.
